title: Gabriela Cámara’s Recipe for Seafood and Chili Poblano Rice
text:
0 COMMENTS ENLARGE YES, SEAR | Blackening the poblano chilies over an open flame before adding them to the rice deepens their flavor and draws out their natural sweetness. Photo: James Ransom for The Wall Street Journal, Food Styling by Ryan Reineck, Prop Styling by Stephanie Hanes The Chef: Gabriela Cámara
ENLARGE Gabriela Cámara Illustration: Michael Hoeweler Her restaurants: Contramar, in Mexico City, and Cala and the forthcoming Tacos Cala, in San Francisco
What she is known for: Introducing flavors from Mexico’s coast to the country’s interior and beyond. Serving rustic, soulful seafood dishes to stylish city dwellers.
AT GABRIELA CÁMARA’S flagship restaurant, Contramar, in Mexico City, the dishes draw on a broad palette of cultural influences , but they’re always approachable. “I only serve food that looks like you can make it at home,” she said, “even if, in some cases, it is just an illusion.”
Simple, nuanced and full of flavor, this recipe, the chef’s second Slow Food Fast contribution, is doable for any home cook.
Think of it as a sort of Mexican risotto. “In Mexico,” Ms. Cámara said, “to make green rice you blend poblano peppers and parsley or cilantro with broth and then cook the rice.” This version skips the herbs and amps up the poblanos with a good char over an open flame. Ms. Cámara uses Bomba rice, a Spanish variety used in paellas that releases starch as it cooks, binding the dish and giving it a silky texture. You can also use Arborio, an Italian variety typically used in risottos. Pieces of mild, tender sand dab complete the comforting meal.
“This recipe is as Mexican as it is Italian or Spanish,” Ms. Cámara said. “It is one we made up years ago that works. Cooking is all about experimenting.”
